description: A 7-kilometer long scenic seaside promenade stretching along the Black Sea coast, featuring lush green spaces, parks, fountains, cafes, and bike paths. One of Batumi's oldest and most beloved attractions with over a century of history.
highlights: 7 km long seaside promenade between the city and Black Sea
Over 140 years of history dating back to 1881
Iconic Batumi Colonnades (1930-1934) - elegant white Greek-style columns
Summer Theater (1948-1949) - striking wooden building constructed without a single nail
Batumi Lighthouse (1882) - 21-meter stone building functioning as hydrographic center
Colorful dancing fountains synchronized with music and lights
Numerous restaurants, beach bars, cafe-lounges, and clubs
Children's amusement rides and Ferris wheel
Designated bike paths for cycling enthusiasts
tips: Visit both during day and night for completely different atmospheres
The dancing fountains are particularly spectacular after dark
Rent a bike to cover the entire 7 km length comfortably
Stop at the numerous cafes along the way for local refreshments
Best time to visit is during spring and summer for pleasant weather
The boulevard is divided into Old Boulevard and New Boulevard (expanded in 2009)
Look for local craft vendors selling jewelry and souvenirs
The area where the lighthouse stands is unique - 41st parallel of longitude and latitude coincide
vibe: Vibrant, relaxing, family-friendly - a perfect blend of natural beauty, cultural heritage, and modern entertainment. The atmosphere shifts from peaceful morning strolls to lively evening gatherings with music, lights, and crowds enjoying the seaside ambiance.
expectations: A well-maintained, clean promenade perfect for leisurely walks
Beautiful sea views throughout the entire stretch
Mix of historical monuments and modern attractions
Family-friendly environment with activities for all ages
Plenty of dining and refreshment options
reality: The boulevard truly delivers on its promises - it's even more impressive in person
The sheer length (7 km) means you'll need time to explore it fully
Can get crowded during peak tourist season and weekends
Some sections are more wooded and shaded, others open to full sun
The combination of old and new sections creates interesting architectural contrasts
Weather can be unpredictable - bring layers even in summer
unique_facts: Construction began in 1881 by German gardeners Rayer and Reseller under Governor Mekalov
French architect Michael D'Alfons renovated the area in French style (1885-1889) and is called the 'Genius of Batumi sea coast'
Designated as a national monument of Georgian garden-park art since 1987
The Spanish architect designed the New Boulevard expansion in 2009
Summer Theater's wooden facade features large round windows and cascading geometric patterns without using a single nail
The lighthouse location marks the unique spot where 41 degree parallels of longitude and latitude coincide
Weather forecasters observe conditions 24/7 from the lighthouse hydrographic center
The boulevard serves as both a cultural heritage monument and active recreational area
surprises: The boulevard is much longer than most tourists expect - 7 km is a substantial walk
A fully functional zoo corner exists right on the boulevard
The Summer Theater's nail-free wooden construction has survived since 1948
Over 40,000 trees planted create an urban forest atmosphere
The New Boulevard section (post-2009) feels like a completely different area with modern Spanish-influenced design
The dancing fountains perform every 10 minutes throughout the evening
Despite being over 140 years old, the boulevard continues to evolve and expand
